query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Guardando nel suo Figlio con l’Amore 2 che l’uno e l’altro etternalmente spira, 3 lo primo e ineffabile Valore
4 quanto per mente e per loco si gira 5 con tant’ ordine fé, ch’esser non puote 6 sanza gustar di lui chi ciò rimira.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Looking in his Son with the Love 2 that the one and the other eternally breathe, 3 the first and ineffable Value
4 as much as it turns through mind and through space 5 with such order did he make, that he who gazes upon this 6 cannot but taste of him.
**Cornish:**
1 Yn gweles yn Y mab gans an Karanteth 2 a spira an dhew oll ankenver, 3 an Kynsa ha'n Gwerth diworth,
4 kement a dro dha breder ha dha le 5 gans hemma urdh a wrug, na allo 6 hep provia a-gan neb a'n gwelo.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Vedi come da indi si dirama 14 l’oblico cerchio che i pianeti porta, 15 per sodisfare al mondo che li chiama.
query.result:
**English:**
13 See how from there branches out 14 the oblique circle that carries the planets, 15 to satisfy the world that calls to them.
**Cornish:**
13 Gweles mar a-dhyworth henna yma yma dhe'n drehedhes 14 an kelgh uhel a dhrehevis an planedhow, 15 rag sodisfya an bys a wra aga galwes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 Or ti riman, lettor, sovra ’l tuo banco, 23 dietro pensando a ciò che si preliba, 24 s’esser vuoi lieto assai prima che stanco.
query.result:
**English:**
22 Now remain, reader, upon your bench, 23 reflecting upon what has been foretasted, 24 if you wish to be joyful long before you are weary.
**Cornish:**
22 Wosa, lenor, warbarth dhe'n fordh, 23 ow tosowgh dhe hemma a veu preliba, 24 mar owth bos meur lowenny kyns bos stanc.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Messo t’ho innanzi: omai per te ti ciba; 26 ché a sé torce tutta la mia cura 27 quella materia ond’ io son fatto scriba.
query.result:
**English:**
25 I have set it before you: now feed yourself on it; 26 for all my care is turned to that subject 27 on which I have been made a writer.
**Cornish:**
25 Yma'm owth settys kyns: wosa dhis dhe'n dhy hunan; 26 rag dhe'n dhi hunan yma owth drehedhes oll ow gof, 27 an mater na'm owth gwres pub skrifor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Lo ministro maggior de la natura, 29 che del valor del ciel lo mondo imprenta 30 e col suo lume il tempo ne misura,
31 con quella parte che sù si rammenta 32 congiunto, si girava per le spire 33 in che più tosto ognora s’appresenta;
34 e io era con lui; ma del salire 35 non m’accors’ io, se non com’ uom s’accorge, 36 anzi ’l primo pensier, del suo venire.
query.result:
**English:**
28 The greatest minister of nature, 29 who imprints the world with the power of the heavens 30 and measures time with his light,
31 was turning, joined with that part which is remembered above, 32 through the coils in which he always appears more quickly;
33 and I was with him; but I did not notice the ascent, 34 except as a man notices, or rather, the first thought, of his coming.
**Cornish:**
28 An mynistr moyha an termyn, 29 a brenj an bys vyth gallos an nef, 30 ha gans an golon henna a mesur an amser,
31 gans an rann henna a wra vythkowsys war-tu, 32 kevrennek, a drohia a-dro dhe'n gylgh, 33 yn aga moy bys vythkwethadhes;
34 ha vy o gans an golon henna; mes na vynnav vy 35 an sevel, mes kepar ha'n den a vynnav, 36 po moy bys vythkwethadhes kyns, y'n dalleth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 È Bëatrice quella che sì scorge 38 di bene in meglio, sì subitamente 39 che l’atto suo per tempo non si sporge.
query.result:
**English:**
37 It is Beatrice who reveals herself 38 from good to better, so suddenly 39 that her action does not extend itself in time.
**Cornish:**
37 Bees Bëatrice henna a wra gwelys 38 a-dhyworth da bys gwell, kemmys vythkweth, 39 may na wra y'n ober a-dro dhe'n termyn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 Quant’ esser convenia da sé lucente 41 quel ch’era dentro al sol dov’ io entra’mi, 42 non per color, ma per lume parvente!
43 Perch’ io lo ’ngegno e l’arte e l’uso chiami, 44 sì nol direi che mai s’imaginasse; 45 ma creder puossi e di veder si brami.
query.result:
**English:**
40 How fitting it was for that which was within the sun, where I entered, 41 to be shining by itself, 42 not by color, but by light, appearing!
43 For which I call upon my intellect, art, and experience, 44 I would not say that it could ever be imagined; 45 but it can be believed and desired to be seen.
**Cornish:**
40 Pythvelyk o anedha dhe bys golow dhe'n honan 41 henna o o an howl, lemmyn vy'm kerdhas, 42 nyns gans liw, mes gans golon, a wra gwelys!
43 Rag henna vy'm galwas war vy an intelleks, an art ha'n defnydh, 44 vy na leverav vy na wra bythkweth ymagynyes; 45 mes yllir ymagynyes ha'ga dhe weles.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 E se le fantasie nostre son basse 47 a tanta altezza, non è maraviglia; 48 ché sopra ’l sol non fu occhio ch’andasse.
query.result:
**English:**
46 And if our imaginations are too low 47 for such a height, it is no wonder; 48 for above the sun there has been no eye that has gone.
**Cornish:**
46 Ha mar yw an fantasi a-gan yw isel 47 dhe'n uhelder magh, nyns yw marghus; 48 rag war-tu an howl nyns eus lagha a dhiskwedhas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Tal era quivi la quarta famiglia 50 de l’alto Padre, che sempre la sazia, 51 mostrando come spira e come figlia.
query.result:
**English:**
49 Such was the fourth family there 50 of the high Father, who always satisfies it, 51 showing how it breathes and how it is his daughter.
**Cornish:**
49 Henna o an peswora peswar 50 a'n Tas uhel, a wra y sia yn byth, 51 ow tiskwedhes pyth yw analan ha pyth yw y vergh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 E Bëatrice cominciò: «Ringrazia, 53 ringrazia il Sol de li angeli, ch’a questo 54 sensibil t’ha levato per sua grazia».
query.result:
**English:**
52 And Beatrice began: "Give thanks, 53 give thanks to the Sun of the angels, who to this 54 sensible world has raised you by his grace."
**Cornish:**
52 Ha Bëatrice a dhallethas: "Dyllergh, 53 dyllergh an Howl a'n eleth, a'th pynnys dhe'n 54 bys-ma gweladow dre y ras."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 Cor di mortal non fu mai sì digesto 56 a divozione e a rendersi a Dio 57 con tutto ’l suo gradir cotanto presto,
58 come a quelle parole mi fec’ io; 59 e sì tutto ’l mio amore in lui si mise, 60 che Bëatrice eclissò ne l’oblio.
query.result:
**English:**
55 Never was the heart of a mortal so disposed 56 to devotion and to surrendering itself to God 57 with all its gratitude so quickly,
58 as I became at those words; 59 and all my love was so placed in him, 60 that Beatrice was eclipsed in oblivion.
**Cornish:**
55 Nyns eus colon den vythkweth mor godhvos 56 dhe dhyvotion ha dhe omdhysk dhe'n Duw 57 gans y holl ras vythkweth mor bys vythkweth,
58 kepar ha vy dhe'n gerow henna; 59 ha henna oll vy'm karanteth a veu settys yndella, 60 byth Bëatrice a veu kudhys y'n an ankoub.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Non le dispiacque; ma sì se ne rise, 62 che lo splendor de li occhi suoi ridenti 63 mia mente unita in più cose divise.
query.result:
**English:**
61 It did not displease her; but she laughed at it, 62 so that the splendor of her smiling eyes 63 divided my united mind into many things.
**Cornish:**
61 Nyns o anedha dhe; mes henna oll a wra ow lowen, 62 byth splannder a'y lagha ow lowen 63 a rann vy'm meynsek unys y'n moyha traow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Io vidi più folgór vivi e vincenti 65 far di noi centro e di sé far corona, 66 più dolci in voce che in vista lucenti:
67 così cinger la figlia di Latona 68 vedem talvolta, quando l’aere è pregno, 69 sì che ritenga il fil che fa la zona.
query.result:
**English:**
64 I saw more living and conquering lightnings 65 making a center of us and a crown of themselves, 66 sweeter in voice than shining in appearance:
67 thus we sometimes see the daughter of Latona encircled, 68 when the air is pregnant, 69 so that it retains the thread that makes the halo.
**Cornish:**
64 Vy'm gwelas moy folgors byw ha gwaynyas 65 ow kul an kres a-dro dhe'n honan, 66 moy dowr y'n an lef a splannder y'n an golwg:
67 henna oll ow kul an vergh dhe Latona 68 ow tosowas, pan yw an ayr leun, 69 henna oll a wra dal an edhen a wra an gwregys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 Poi, sì cantando, quelli ardenti soli 77 si fuor girati intorno a noi tre volte, 78 come stelle vicine a’ fermi poli,
79 donne mi parver, non da ballo sciolte, 80 ma che s’arrestin tacite, ascoltando 81 fin che le nove note hanno ricolte.
query.result:
**English:**
76 Then, singing thus, those burning suns 77 turned around us three times, 78 like stars close to the fixed poles.
79 They seemed to me to be ladies, not freed from dancing, 80 but who stand still, listening silently, 81 until they have gathered the new notes.
**Cornish:**
76 Wosa, kanas gwelow, an heuliow tomm 77 a dreylyas war droyn tri gweyth, 78 kepar sterennow ogas dhe'n poliow fast.
79 Meraseth o wrug y'm gweles, nag esa drefes, 80 mes a wra esa sevel heb ger, klevas, 81 bys dhe notenn nowyth esa dastummes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 E dentro a l’un senti’ cominciar: «Quando 83 lo raggio de la grazia, onde s’accende 84 verace amore e che poi cresce amando,
85 multiplicato in te tanto resplende, 86 che ti conduce su per quella scala 87 u’ sanza risalir nessun discende;
88 qual ti negasse il vin de la sua fiala 89 per la tua sete, in libertà non fora 90 se non com’ acqua ch’al mar non si cala.
query.result:
**English:**
82 And within one I heard begin: "When 83 the ray of grace, from which true love is kindled 84 and which then grows through loving,
85 multiplied in you shines so brightly 86 that it leads you up that ladder 87 from which no one descends without ascending;
88 who would deny you the wine from his flask 89 for your thirst would not be free, 90 except as water that does not flow into the sea.
**Cornish:**
82 Ha'gasowethonanowethplegyas: "Pandr' 83 anpelldergras, agesavynneth, 84 karantegasowethhakar,
85 liesowethynnosplenndyas, 86 agesavynneth warbarth anledder 87 agesavynneth nynsavynneth dissendyas;
88 pyw a'th omdhyn an gwin a'y flasket 89 rag an seth, yn frank, nynso bydh, 90 mes agesavynneth dowr nynso a wra dhe'n mor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Tu vuo’ saper di quai piante s’infiora 92 questa ghirlanda che ’ntorno vagheggia 93 la bella donna ch’al ciel t’avvalora.
query.result:
**English:**
91 You want to know with what plants is adorned 92 this garland that encircles and beautifies 93 the fair lady who gives you strength for heaven.
**Cornish:**
91 Whens dha wodhya gans an plansoweth a wra floryes 92 an gerlann-ma a wra'n-dro warbarth ha'gas 93 an vorow benen a wra'th gorra dhe'n nef.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Io fui de li agni de la santa greggia 95 che Domenico mena per cammino 96 u’ ben s’impingua se non si vaneggia.
query.result:
**English:**
94 I was one of the sheep of the holy flock 95 that Dominic leads along the path 96 where one truly fattens if one does not stray.
**Cornish:**
94 My a veu unn a'n tanow an greg gregys 95 a wra menys gans Domynnyk war an fordh 96 agesavynneth mar plen an den nyns yw fol.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Questi che m’è a destra più vicino, 98 frate e maestro fummi, ed esso Alberto 99 è di Cologna, e io Thomas d’Aquino.
query.result:
**English:**
97 This one who is closest to me on the right, 98 was my brother and teacher, and he is Albert 99 of Cologne, and I am Thomas Aquinas.
**Cornish:**
97 An onan-ma a wra dhe'n dhew dhe'n fordh, 98 froder ha mester o'm veu, hag ev Albert 99 a Golon, ha my Thomas Akwinas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Se sì di tutti li altri esser vuo’ certo, 101 di retro al mio parlar ten vien col viso 102 girando su per lo beato serto.
query.result:
**English:**
100 If you wish to be certain of all the others, 101 follow my words with your gaze 102 as you circle around the blessed garland.
**Cornish:**
100 Mar whens dha wodhya sur a'n remenans, 101 wosa'm lavar, dell wosa'th fyllel dha drog 102 a wra tro' war an serth benenes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Quell’ altro fiammeggiare esce del riso 104 di Grazïan, che l’uno e l’altro foro 105 aiutò sì che piace in paradiso.
query.result:
**English:**
103 That other shining comes from the smile 104 of Gratian, who helped both the one and the other 105 so that they are pleasing in paradise.
**Cornish:**
103 An losk arall a wra'n-dro a wra'n-dro a'n golgh 104 a Gratian, a skoesas an dhew ha'n arall 105 mar plegas mar plegas yn paradys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 L’altro ch’appresso addorna il nostro coro, 107 quel Pietro fu che con la poverella 108 offerse a Santa Chiesa suo tesoro.
query.result:
**English:**
106 The other who next adorns our choir, 107 was that Peter who with the poor woman 108 offered his treasure to Holy Church.
**Cornish:**
106 An aral syw nessa'gas ollvyas agan kor, 107 henna o Pedyr a wrug gans an benyn 108 dalleth y thresor dhe Eglos Sans.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 La quinta luce, ch’è tra noi più bella, 110 spira di tale amor, che tutto ’l mondo 111 là giù ne gola di saper novella:
112 entro v’è l’alta mente u’ sì profondo 113 saver fu messo, che, se ’l vero è vero, 114 a veder tanto non surse il secondo.
query.result:
**English:**
109 The fifth light, which is the most beautiful among us, 110 breathes with such love that the whole world 111 down there thirsts to know the news:
112 within it is the lofty mind in which such profound 113 knowledge was placed, that, if the truth is true, 114 no second has ever risen to see so much.
**Cornish:**
109 An pympes golow, an moyha brassa genen, 110 a spira gans karanteth poes, an oll an bys 111 a-woles yno dhe wodhya nowodhow:
112 Mes yma an mentol uhel le mayth 113 goweth poes o settys, mar yw an gwir gwir, 114 nyns yw eyl eyl ow tos dhe weles kemmys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 Appresso vedi il lume di quel cero 116 che giù in carne più a dentro vide 117 l’angelica natura e ’l ministero.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Next you see the light of that candle 116 who down below in the flesh saw most deeply 117 the angelic nature and its ministry.
**Cornish:**
115 Wosa henna gweles golow henna kannel 116 a wrug y’n korf moy es dhe weles 117 an naturel angelek ha’y ober.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Ne l’altra piccioletta luce ride 119 quello avvocato de’ tempi cristiani 120 del cui latino Augustin si provide.
query.result:
**English:**
118 In the other little light smiles 119 that advocate of Christian times 120 from whose Latin Augustine drew nourishment.
**Cornish:**
118 Y’n aral golow byghan a wra dhaffar 119 henna avokat a’n termyn Kristyon 120 a’y Latin ow tos Augustine boos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 Or se tu l’occhio de la mente trani 122 di luce in luce dietro a le mie lode, 123 già de l’ottava con sete rimani.
query.result:
**English:**
121 Now if you, with the eye of your mind, 122 pass from light to light, following my praises, 123 you are already thirsting for the eighth.
**Cornish:**
121 Mes wosa’th ow, gans an lagha a’th mentol, 122 ow tos a golow dhe golow wosa’m gweles, 123 ow yw ow tos dhe ethves gans syth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Per vedere ogne ben dentro vi gode 125 l’anima santa che ’l mondo fallace 126 fa manifesto a chi di lei ben ode.
query.result:
**English:**
124 To see every good thing, the holy soul rejoices within it, 125 who makes the deceitful world 126 manifest to those who listen well to her.
**Cornish:**
124 Rag gweles pub tra a wra’n lowen y’n mes 125 an eneval sans a wra an bys fals 126 kler dhe’n neb a wra dhe’y gweles brav.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Lo corpo ond’ ella fu cacciata giace 128 giuso in Cieldauro; ed essa da martiro 129 e da essilio venne a questa pace.
query.result:
**English:**
127 The body from which she was expelled lies 128 down below in Cieldauro; and she from martyrdom 129 and from exile came to this peace.
**Cornish:**
127 An korf a-dhia henna o ve thyghes 128 y’n-nans yn Kieldauro; ha henna a verter 129 ha a-dhia esili a dhe’n peth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Vedi oltre fiammeggiar l’ardente spiro 131 d’Isidoro, di Beda e di Riccardo, 132 che a considerar fu più che viro.
query.result:
**English:**
130 See beyond, flaming with ardent spirit, 131 Isidore, Bede, and Richard, 132 who was more than a man in contemplation.
**Cornish:**
130 Gweles ogas an flammow an speres tomm 131 Isidore, Beda ha Ryszard, 132 neb o ve moy es den y’n studhya.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Questi onde a me ritorna il tuo riguardo, 134 è ’l lume d’uno spirto che ’n pensieri 135 gravi a morir li parve venir tardo:
136 essa è la luce etterna di Sigieri, 137 che, leggendo nel Vico de li Strami, 138 silogizzò invidïosi veri».
query.result:
**English:**
133 This one to whom your gaze returns, 134 is the light of a spirit who in grave 135 thoughts seemed to come slowly to death:
136 it is the eternal light of Siger, 137 who, reading in the Rue du Fouarre, 138 syllogized envious truths.
**Cornish:**
133 Henna neb dhe’n wra’th ow golwg dhe’th dro, 134 yw golow a speres neb y’n menowgh 135 tomm o dhe ves marow:
136 henna yw golow travoyl Sigieri, 137 neb, ow studhya y’n Rue du Fouarre, 138 a syllogisa gwirioweth genvyskys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 Indi, come orologio che ne chiami 140 ne l’ora che la sposa di Dio surge 141 a mattinar lo sposo perché l’ami,
142 che l’una parte e l’altra tira e urge, 143 tin tin sonando con sì dolce nota, 144 che ’l ben disposto spirto d’amor turge;
145 così vid’ ïo la gloriosa rota 146 muoversi e render voce a voce in tempra 147 e in dolcezza ch’esser non pò nota
148 se non colà dove gioir s’insempra.
query.result:
**English:**
139 Then, like a clock that calls us 140 at the hour when God's bride rises 141 to wake her spouse so that he may love her,
142 which draws and urges one part and the other, 143 sounding tin tin with such a sweet note, 144 that the well-disposed spirit swells with love;
145 so I saw the glorious wheel 146 move and render voice to voice in harmony 147 and in a sweetness that cannot be known
148 except there where joy is sempiternal.
**Cornish:**
139 Wosa henna, kepar orolog a wra’n galow 140 y’n eur pan vro Godh a wra’n sevel 141 dhe brederi y’n gwreg rag karas an ef,
142 neb a wra tenna ha tenna ha’y galow, 143 ow sona tin tin gans noten kemmys dowr, 144 bys an speres brav o karanteth ow turj;
145 kepar henna gweles i an roda glorius 146 ow tos ha rei leun dhe leun y’n tempra 147 ha y’n dowrder nyns yw possybel dhe wodhya
148 mar nyns yw le mayth sempiternal.
